American-Libertarians are the polar opposite of "radical". They are reactionaries.

That's linguistic prescriptivism. Words change meaning over time, constantly. Just go to /r/badlinguistics, which is full of your anarchist friends.
However, the original use of the term "libertarian" was as *a defender of liberty*, i.e. liberals, when the London Packet wrote (in 1796): "Lately marched out of the Prison at Bristol, 450 of the French Libertarians."
It was used again by the same paper in 1802 critiquing a poem thusly:
"The author's Latin verses, which are rather more intelligible than his English, mark him for a furious Libertarian (if we may coin such a term) and a zealous admirer of France, and her liberty, under Bonaparte; such liberty!"
Ah, a supporter of the French Revolution - a liberal, then, not a socialist!
DeJacque did not use the term to mean "anarchist" until 1857, more than half a century later!
Now, aside from the fact that words change meaning, it's pretty clear that "libertarian" was originally meant to mean a radical liberal, which is exactly what it means today in common parlance. Ironically, despite anarchists constantly bemoaning libertarians "stealing" their word (how ironic! You own nothing!), it's the anarchists who stole the word libertarian - based on their own warped concept of freedom.
Yeah that's the joke! Hey man I'm glad you got it. I thought it might have slipped past you.

You have not suggested any significant cultural or historical differences you have with New York City,
We are far more Protestant - in particular there are a lot of Methodist and Reformed churches. (The Reformed churches being leftovers of Dutch colonial rule - our Dutch heritage is still a big thing here, just look at the flag of Albany.) Ever heard of the Burned-Over District? One of the epicenters of the Second Great Awakening? Oh, and Mormonism was founded in upstate New York, by Joseph Smith (I'm ashamed to say he's a distant relative of mine). NYC, by contrast, is largely Catholic, non-Christian, or irreligious.
We have much different demographics. We have more Germans, Dutch, and English people, as compared to NYC's large number of Italians and non-whites.
Many areas in North Country have large amounts of French-Canadians. In Potsdam and Canton, you'll see Canadian flags flying. People speak French and love poutine there, and large areas of northern NY receive Canadian TV broadcasts.
Upstate New York's dialect is actually closer to the Inland North dialect spoken in the midwest and parts of Canada than it is to downstate New York.
We have a long history of secessionism, going back to 1969 - a lot of people in NYC even support secession, like Norman Mailer and Jimmy Breslin, who ran for office on a NYC secession ticket. Liberals in NYC and conservatives upstate often want to secede. The entire state of Vermont seceded from New York, and upstate NY is similar to Vermont in many ways.
As I outlined previously, which you completely ignored, we haven't had a governor from upstate in nearly a century and we have our first senator from upstate in 50 years. No fucking wonder upstate is rotting - despite your claim that "we elected these people", *upstate routinely votes against the people who win*, because NYC voters have different wants and needs than we do and they outnumber us.
That is the crux of my argument. It's not "rural vs urban", it's "upstate vs downstate". I'd be fine with electing people from Buffalo, Albany, Rochester, Syracuse, Ithaca, etc (I *live* in Albany for fuck's sake), because they at least share a similar outlook and understand the upstate economy, which is largely agrarian and factory-based, as opposed to downstate's economy.
You completely ignored every argument I made in favor of your arrogant snobbery against "those stupid parochial Americans". Simply pathetic.
Oh, and your country held a referendum on Scottish independence - which has about the same claim to independence as upstate.
you have outright said you want your vote to be more powerful than the vote of someone in NYC
I want both of us to be able to select governors and senators who share our cultural background and understand the issues of our area. How is that "more powerful" than someone in NYC?
you have insulted the truly important independence movements of the world by trying to compare yourself petty gripes with local government to them.
...How is it insulting to say that I also have valid complaints? Is it insulting to say you're hungry because some people are starving? Did I ever compare myself to the Tibetans or any other group of people who want to secede? Or is that just your assumption?

I'm not going to bother responding to every point you made, since half of them are nonsensical and the rest is snobbery.
You don't live here. You've never been here.
I don't want my votes to be "more powerful". I want my votes to matter, and I want politicians to be elected who actually understand issues affecting me.
Fix your crappy electoral college and most of your complaints would be gone anyway.
Not even remotely, bud.
That's kind of what I'm saying. It's just a very liberal Christian sect.

If you think NYC and upstate New York aren't "culturally or historically distinct", you've clearly never been here and have no idea how the people here feel. Religiously, demographically, politically, culturally, we are distinct from New York City. I go to NYC every year and it's a magical land of enchantment - certainly not home.
But hey, typical Euro making assumptions about places they've never been to.
The limited influence upstate has, while proportional, leaves our part of the state at the mercy of people from a self-contained city, most of whom have never been up here except perhaps for a vacation at Lake George. We pay obscenely high taxes for programs we don't want, our votes effectively do not matter, and our interests are ignored in favor of NYC's interests.
Have you ever heard of Utica? It's called "the city God forgot" because our state has allowed it to die. Upstate is rotting with no help from downstaters, who by and large have no idea.
Furthermore, upstate is tightly contested between Republicans and Democrats. Right now our votes don't matter. As an independent state we would be one of the largest swing states. Politicians would actually bother campaigning here. Our votes would matter, rather than being drowned out by the Democratic horde in NYC. The government might bother investing here.
We would have a governor with our customs, who understands and cares about our problems. (We haven't had a governor from upstate since Nathan Miller, 1921-1922.) We would have two senators from upstate. (Kirsten Gilibrand is from upstate, but before her our last upstate senator was Charles Goodell, 1968.)
By every measure, we would be better off independent, and the people here broadly support it. You're basically saying "shut up and like it" without actually understanding anything about the area.
Policies all come from books, ultimately.

We are not trying to secede from the United States. We are trying to secede from New York and form our own state within the United States. Devolution in Scotland, Wales and NI is more comparable to it than, say, Catalonian independence.
I can't speak for him, but personally, whenever Petersen speaks he seems really smug and pretentious.
Thank fuck. Adam Kokesh 2020!
